text: - Welcome to "Back to Basics".
In this episode, I will discuss choosing
and using the right storage option
for optimal application performance.
AWS has many storage offerings,

each meeting different
needs for your workloads.
I'll help you demystify the offerings
through patterns you can use
to leverage the right storage services.
Let's say you're a global enterprise
running various applications.

You likely have many different
kinds of storage requirements
for different workloads.

One of your applications might
be a public-facing website.

You can use Amazon Simple
Storage Service, or S3,
to host the static assets of the website,
like images and videos.
Because Amazon S3 is an object store
that offers industry-leading scalability,
availability, and security,

you can store and retrieve any
amount of data from anywhere.
You should use Amazon S3

for read-heavy workloads
requiring object storage,
such as content distribution, web hosting,
big data analytics, and ML workflows.
It is well suited for scenarios

where data needs to be stored
and accessed via an API

and distributed globally
over the internet.
Amazon S3 is highly scalable,

and you do not need to worry
about provisioning storage
or expanding storage for S3,

and you will only pay
for the amount of storage
you are currently using.
Another enterprise application

may require Amazon Elastic
Compute Cloud, or EC2,
that run your core workloads.

This workload could be batch
processed on an ERP system

that requires high
throughput and low latency.

To support EC2, you need
Elastic Block Store, or EBS.
As the name indicates,

EBS is an easy-to-use
high-performance block storage service

for both throughput and
transaction-intensive workloads
at scale.

Block storage offers
high-performance, durable storage
that is direct attached to an instance
to meet these workload requirements.

EBS volumes can behave like
raw, unformatted block devices
backed by disks of different types.
Keep in mind though that unlike S3,

an EBS drive can only be
attached to one entity at a time.

So if your workloads run
in a cluster like big data
or machine-learning workloads

and have such a requirement
for shared storage,
then EFS or FSx will be better suited.
In the case of Amazon FSx, it is designed
to provide an easy and cost-effective way
to launch, run, and scale

feature-rich, high-performance
file systems in the cloud.
It supports a range of workloads.
With FSx, you can choose
between four widely-used file systems,
Lustre, NetApp ONTAP,
OpenZFS, and Windows File Server.
This choice is typically based

on your familiarity
with a given file system

or on matching the file
systems' feature sets,

performance profiles, and
data management capabilities
to the requirements of your workloads.
Be sure to select one
that closely matches your requirements.
In the use cases previously mentioned,

let's say you do not know
the amount of storage

that would be required,
or the usage profile.
In those cases,
Amazon Elastic File System, or Amazon EFS,

provides serverless,
fully elastic file storage

so that you can share file
data without provisioning

or managing storage,
capacity, and performance.

Amazon EFS is built to
scale on demand to petabytes
without disrupting applications,
growing and shrinking automatically
as you add and remove files.
You can use EFS for applications

and workloads requiring
shared read and write access
across multiple EC2 instances, containers,
or from multiple on-premises servers,
such as Team file shares,
highly-available enterprise applications,

analytics workloads, and
ML-training workloads.
On the other hand,

applications that require
usage of SMB protocol
can use FSx for Windows instead of EFS.
With EFS, you don't have to worry
about provisioning a certain size.

So whether your application
is one terabytes

or one petabyte, EFS
will automatically grow
as your storage size increases.
Finally, Amazon File Cache

is a fully-managed,
high-speed cache on AWS
that is used to process file data,
regardless of where that data is stored.

It serves as a temporary,
high-performance storage location

for data that is stored in
on-premises file systems,
FSx, and S3 buckets.
As the name indicates,
you can use File Cache either standalone

or in combination with
other AWS storage offerings
to offer better performance
for very latency-sensitive workloads.
General cache best practices
also apply to Amazon File Cache.
In this episode,

we discussed the different
storage options available in AWS

and how you can correctly select
the right storage offering
based on your workload and usage patterns.
I hope this provides guidance

as you're launching and
running your workloads.
For more information,

check out the links in
the description below.

Thanks for watching "Back to
Basics". See you next time.
